I also prefer objective analyses. But when a 'human life' begins is a subjective question.  It is not like defining 'life,' which has its own problems. Some would say that viruses are not life because there is no metabolism (I disagree). But as for defining when a human life begins, some would say at conception, but there are a host of other possible definitions based upon the science we know. Science can inform our opinions, but they remain opinions ... not objective facts.

So 'life' on Mars is a totally different question. An unfertilized egg is also 'life', but it is not a human life, though it has potential to become one, at whatever stage we subjectively opine.

Yes, Peter does note Noah in that chapter, but it is interesting that he doesn't mention a global flood, or the animals that God spared on the Ark in that parable.
Yes, I know you believe the parables literally, but that is a distortion of their purpose. Certainly their purpose was not to deny reality that is so plainly obvious to those who care to observe the natural world. As Paul wrote to Timothy, the "All scripture is God-breathed and is useful ..." (here you go: 2 Timothy 3:16). I find the Holy Bible to be very useful, and it appears to be useful to you as well to calm your soul. But it loses its usefulness when God-breathed parables are distorted as unerring history.

" But they deliberately forget that long ago by God’s word the heavens came into being and the earth was formed out of water and by water. By these waters also the world of that time was deluged and destroyed."
– 2 Peter 3.5 - 6

Ummm ... Peter mentions the flood. That's what "deluge" means.

What makes you think the flood narrative is a parable? There is no indication that it is a parable. Jesus mentions Noah and the flood but gives no indication that it was a parable. Peter is not treating it as a parable. Which one of us is distorting Scripture? You reject the truth of the Word of God. It's just that simple. (Luke 7.11 - 17) Did Jesus really raise the daughter of Jairus from the dead or was that a parable? (Luke 8.40 – 56) How about Jesus himself? Did Jesus really rise from the dead or is that another parable? Is the whole Scripture nothing but parables? How exactly do you distinguish between true historical narrative and parable?

"But as the days of Noah were, so also will the coming of the Son of Man be. – Matthew 24.37 - 39

Jesus doesn't sound like he's treating the flood as a parable.

The flood narrative is a parable because a global flood never happened in historic times, and all people and animals were not wiped out 4370 years ago.  Look a North American archaeology, and the continuity of peoples before and after that time.
The earliest known writing predates that time, and there is no mention in writing of such a great flood around that time, except in your interpretation of Genesis.

Writings aside, there is no evidence of a global flood geologically. I've seen you cite the Grand Canyon, but that is just silliness beyond reality.

Would God flood the world and leave no geological trace? That would be a deceitful god. My God is a loving God, and reveals Himself through all of nature, well beyond the passages he breathed to mere human writers.

No geological trace? Are you kidding?

Hmmm ... Let's see ... What would it look like if there had been a global flood a few thousand years ago? Perhaps there would be layer upon layer of sedimentary (that means "formed from sediment deposited by water") rock all over the Earth filled with the fossils of dead things. Gee ... that's exactly what we find all over the Earth. The same sedimentary layers all over the Earth, as if they had all been created at the same time by the same event ... all over the Earth.

The same geological layers that you find from top to bottom of the Grand Canyon extend all over North America and can be found in Europe, Central Asia, Eastern Asia, Africa, South America ... all over the Earth – the same layers with the same thicknesses and the same composition and filled with fossils of dead things – as if they had all been created at the same time by the same event.
--------------------------------------------

Let me change the topic a bit and ask you a question. Does your "loving God" have the wisdom and power to create the Earth from nothing in a moment by a mere spoken word? Does your "loving God" have the wisdom and power to create 90 billion lightyears of universe filled with stars and galaxies out of nothing in a moment by a mere spoken word? Does your God have that kind of power and wisdom? If He does, then I challenge you to think of the implications. If your God doesn't have that kind of power and wisdom then my God is bigger than your god.

"Layer upon layer of sedimentary (that means "formed from sediment deposited 
by water") rock all over the Earth filled with the fossils of dead things." That is not what a massive flood would look like at all, and whoever told you that is completely dishonest and non-scientific. What's worse is that you blindly took these geological impossibilities at face value without the slightest bit of intellectual curiosity to read more about how sedimentation (not always by water) actually works.

Let's get on to the God questions.
"Does your "loving God" have the wisdom and power to create the Earth from nothing in a moment by a mere spoken word?" I don't know, as a mere human I can only understand a fraction of God. But I do think that God would not consider it wise to create that way, because He didn't, and I trust His wisdom.
"...  to create 90 billion lightyears of universe filled with stars and galaxies out of nothing in a moment by a mere spoken word? " That sounds like the Big Bang hypothesis. And I don't know how that would reflect wisdom if it is all for just one tiny little planet with life and humans, as you claim. It would be incredibly wasteful.
"If your God doesn't have that kind of power and wisdom then my God is bigger than your God." There is only one God, and you sound like  teenage boys comparing the size of their junk.
The one God of the universe has His ways, and those are cosmic and biological evolution. I trust His wisdom in using those forms of creation.
Mars is a lot of rocks, accumulated over time, in straigrphic layers like the walls of the Grand Canyon, only without the succession of fossils.
Is there new material accumulating? Where does it come from ... space?

Of course there is new material accumulating. Some of it comes from space in the form of meteorites. In some cases, rocks come from life. Dolomite is a kind of limestone that formed at the sea floor as products of life of sea organisms being built up over millions of years. Plate tectonics eventually pushed those dolomites up into continents, the evidence of which is seen in rock outcrops around the world.
Without going on about world dolomites, some in the walls of the Grand Canyon,  the bedrock at one of my fossil sites, at the edge of the Kalahari desert, is made of dolomite (which does not form above ground). Water tables form within the pre-Cambrian dolomitic limestone, and come out as springs. These springs deposit limestone-laden water as tufa, so once again, life forms rock.
At this fossil site, which houses one representative of our ancestors and many ancestors of other living species, one can count thousands of layers of tufa. Tufa, at best, forms one layer a year.
So at one site, your young Earth proposal is easily disproven, and your ideas of a global flood are destroyed.

Sorry, but scientific facts and the Holy Bible are with me on this one. Genesis 1:2: Now Earth was formless and empty. So abiogenesis happened, How it did By God's hand neither of us knows. But Biblically, abiogenesis happened.

Response to "biological evolution," Part 1

The connection between abiogenesis and Darwinian evolution is inextricable. (Let's be clear – "evolution" simply means "change over time." Various definitions for "evolution" are used by arguers for their own convenience. What we are discussing is Darwinian evolution, which has the idea of a "last common ancestor" and that all varieties of life, from oak trees to elephants, descended from one common ancestor. This is foreign to the creation of the various kinds of creatures described in Genesis 1. Even the notion that all mammals or all reptiles or all plants descended from common ancestors is foreign to the creation narrative. There is no ancestral relationship even between dogs and cats, though these two kinds of creatures have many similarities. They were created separately.) Without abiogenesis happening, neither does Darwinian evolution happen, for, without life, there could be no Darwinian evolution. However, to be clear, even with life, there is still no Darwinian evolution. Each of the various kinds of creatures on Earth were created complete and distinct. While, for example, dogs have evolved into many varieties of dogs, all of them are still dogs and they have always been dogs since they were created. Dogs have never been anything other than dogs and have no ancestral relationships with any other creatures.

The quote from Jesus indicates that God made Man as man, not as some protozoan that evolved into Man.

No, it is not "mathematically impossible."  

If there are 100,000,000,000 planets in the universe--and yes, I know there are more--only one would be the first planet with life.  There is a probability of 1 in 100,000,000,000 that the planet was Earth, and others may not have developed life as of yet.

What does that have to do with being mathematically impossible?

It was mathematically impossible for the Earth to be the center of the solar system and the universe. Yet up until the 17th century, creationist were convinced the Earth was the center. A great scientist name Giordano Bruno provided mathematical evidence the Earth was not the center. Bruno was told to retract his findings or face tribunal. Bruno refused and the Pope had him burned at the stake for heresy. It was just 20 years later Galileo provided the same evidence. 

I stand by my words. It is mathematically impossible Earth harbors the only living organisms in the universe. It's only a matter of time until evidence is produced. And even when the evidence is produced, creationists will dismiss it, just as they did in the 17th century.

Keep arguing nonsense. All you did by highlighting one case of a scientific theory being refuted is prove that science is not infallible. There is a mathematical possibility, however small, that we are the only planet with life in the entire universe. I don't say this out of arrogance or religious belief, although I must say your unshakeable belief without proof is more akin to the arrogance of religion than science.

If I find a single diamond ring on a beach, does that mean there are more diamond rings on the beach?  Maybe, maybe not. Until I find a second one, I will say probably not.  I am certainly not going to insist the beach is filled with diamond rings until I do.
